title: My husband deferred his state pension but is being refused a lump sum
text:
My husband deferred his state pension when he reached retirement age at 65 - he was born in April 1951.

However, when he contacted the Government Pension Service to stop the deferral last month and say he would like the £24,500 pot of money he has saved, he was advised he can only take £8,000 and the balance will be split over future years at £18 per week.

As you can imagine, this was a shock to us as my husband is not in very good health and we had plans for what he wanted to do with his pension.

Shock news: My husband deferred his state pension and wants it as a lump sum now - but was told 'no' (Stock image)

He was never advised he would not be entitled to the full amount when he advised the Government he would like to defer his pension.

I also deferred my pension which has accumulated to £34,000, although they advised myself that I can take the full amount because my date of birth is OK - in August 1952.

For my husband to be paid his savings he would have to live for 17 years.

He did not received any information on this when he deferred his state pension. If he had he wouldn't have taken this option. It is a disgrace.

We did not expect this to happen and feel the Government has stolen his savings. And more annoying, he contacted the Government a year previously and they advised him of the amount he would receive and again did NOT advise that he cannot have the money.

Looking back at this time, I reckon the person at the state pension office was not familiar with the new ruling themselves, hence the reason he was not informed.

If possible could you please advise what we can do to make them pay up.

Steve Webb: Find out how to ask the former Pensions Minister a question about your retirement savings in the box below

Steve Webb replies: There was a major change to the state pension system on 6 April 2016 and part of that reform related to the rules around deferring your state pension.

Your husband reached state pension age just a few days into the new regime and so the new rules apply to him.

Your state pension age is before the change - you are younger, but women's state pension age was still lower then - and therefore the old rules applied to you.

How did the deferral rules affect you?

Under the old rules, you had two options if you chose to defer.

One option was to roll up all of the deferred payments as a lump sum (plus interest) which you are planning to do.

The other option was to take an enhanced state pension, with an extra 10.4 per cent on the pension for each year of deferral.

This additional rate was very attractive and means that most people will more than make up in retirement what they gave up by deferring.

What are the new rules that affect your husband?

For those, such as your husband, who reached pension age under the new system, the option of a deferral lump sum has been abolished.

The only option now is to take an enhanced pension when it finally comes into payment. The rate of enhancement is now an extra 5.8 per cent for each year of deferral.

As you say, this means that your husband will recover the missed payments in full after about 17 years of retirement.

The official statistics say that the typical 65 year-old man can expect to live for 21 years, so should on average benefit, but obviously this depends on their state of health.

I can see that it is slightly confusing that your husband has been allowed a lump sum payment of around £8,000 (rather than no lump sum at all).

What I assume has happened here is that the DWP have treated him *as if* he was making a late claim one year after his state pension age.

Because you can make a (non-deferred) claim up to a year after pension age and have it backdated, this first year's money can then be paid as a lump sum.

The balance of the deferred money has then been converted into an enhanced weekly state pension.

What can you and your husband do now?

I do understand your point that your husband had assumed he could do the same as you and claim a lump sum rather than receive an enhanced pension.

I'm afraid there's no obvious way you can get the Department for Work and Pensions to pay a full lump sum as there's no legal basis for it to do so for those who reach pension age from 6 April 2016.

Your best hope would be to make a complaint via your MP to the Parliamentary Ombudsman.

The Ombudsman looks at cases where people have suffered loss due to 'maladministration'.

You would have to demonstrate that DWP provided you with misleading information – perhaps sending you an out-of-date leaflet or (if you can prove this) giving you inaccurate information over the phone.

You can only complain to the Parliamentary Ombudsman if you have first exhausted the complaints process with the relevant Department and you would need to show that you had suffered loss as a result of their failure.

You can find more about the work of the Parliamentary Ombudsman here.
